The viewer who asked in chat about the altitude going back down probably noticed the altitude peaked at 221 km about T +6 minutes then dropped to 217 km at SECO. I believe this maneuver is intended to avoid G force "black zones" in a manned mission abort situation. IIRC, even in unmanned missions a little downward curve before stage separation might help carry extra energy into orbit.

the 1st stage landed nearly centered, the ocean was trying to claim it but failed, way to go spaceX I seriously had my doubts about the size and hull profile but its working!  If you can Tim, ask Elon about the stability control on the drone ship landing pads.  Wondering about the isopod HP/blade size and pitch, and if they are variable pitch.  Also wondering if they use any dynamic ballasting to make it sit lower in the water.  There are things called 'flappers' that are two plates of material with a hinge in the middle that only folds one way, when dropped in the water column they fold and move easily, when pulled upward they do not fold and thus create a large plane of resistance.  When deployed over the rails of a boat or ship they hold the rail of a vessel lower in the water when a swell tries to lift it, as the device is lower than the center of the wave energy in the water, so for large swells and a small boat it has little effect as it rides up the wave with the vessel.  But for a barge in chop its pretty much what they are for, damping the motion of the vessel, good for working on deck on commercial boats that are stationary in crappy weather.

My biggest question is about the cycle time on getting that booster operational again.  One of the issues with STS was that the "reusable" SSME's needed major work between flights.  Just how much does it cost to service the Merlin engines between launches, and does it really represent a cost saving over discardable boosters.  The first thought that pops into my mind is that obviously this is better and more efficient, but the issue is not so much an engineering question as it is an accounting question.  How much money is being saved?

On a subject of ssto: I would really like to see a deep look into hybrid scramjet/airspike/ducted rocket engines. It's basicaly a scramjet with the specific impulse that comes with that, but it can also provide useful thrust becuase of airflow is provided by the rocket nozzles/fuel enjectors mounted inside it that burn fuel rich at the start to utilize atmospheric oxygen and could potentially switch to fuel only during hypersonic flight. Higher performance is also achived due to regular thermal expansion of the air inside engines allowing more thermal energy to be used for propulsion then in conventional design. Also if your craft is designed to injest boundry layer all around your craft (which it really should be as it lets you avoid air turbulence behind it reducing drag in the process) and you are using evaporative cooling starship style, you can reuse that fuel for propulsion too.


Apparently NASA looked into that back in the day, it isn't something new and seems like a perfect fit for an ssto as the main advantage of those is utilizing atmosphere to reach orbit with thrust to weight ratio less than zero and way less propellant due to high specific impulse only bested by nuclear engines.


All of that looks really good on paper, wonder why that design never flown (to space, apparently there are missiles using this kind of engine now).
